description.narrative: The UNDP approach to community reconciliation can be characterized as: Locally-led, Victim-centred and forgiveness orientated, Inclusive (not partisan or excluding), and Civic-minded (not tribal/sectarian)

sector.narrative: Build resilience to shocks and crisis

description.narrative:
Indicators established in 2017:
Output 1: Awareness campaigns to inform target communities of the peace committees and 'Citizen Archive' are designed and carried out 1.1 # of Iraqi champions of reconciliation recruited 1.2. # of Iraqi champions capacitated 1.3 % increase of individuals who believe reconciliation can be achieved 1.4 # of successful campaigns carried out in the project locations 1.5 # of baseline studies conducted
Outcome 2: Active effective networks of Local Reconciliation Committees established
2.1 # of Local Peace Committees functioning 2.2 # of collective interaction between LRCs in communities across targeted areas 2.3 # of evidence of collective interaction between LRCs and higher level mechanisms 2.4 # Development of social cohesion measurement tool 2.5 # One nation-wide community reconciliation conference 2.6 # of vulnerable group representatives (women, youth, minorities) actively participating with LRCs
Output 3: Partners to conduct joint preparatory work towards the establishment of a Citizens Archive
3.1 # of consultations and dialogue sessions carried out
New indicators as of 2019:
Output 1: Reconciliation and social cohesion awareness campaigns in target communities are designed and carried out
1.1 # of Iraqi champions of reconciliation recruited and capacitated (disaggregated by gender) 1.2 # of of public awareness campaigns on social cohesion conducted
Output 2: Active effective networks of Community Peace Platforms are established
2.1 # of Local Peace Committees established and functioning 2.2 #of youth peace groups established and functioning 2.3 #of nation-wide community reconciliation conferences held 2.4 #of media professionals trained (gender disaggregated
Output 3 Vulnerable women and girls provided with psychosocial support and support creation of women peace groups
3.1 # of female social workers trained to provide support to victims of SGBV 3.2 # of women and girls reached for psychosocial support 3.3 # of wom

comment.narrative:
Baselines established in 2017:
Output 1: Awareness campaigns to inform target communities of the peace committees and 'Citizen Archive' are designed and carried out All baselines TBD.
Outcome 2: Active effective networks of Local Reconciliation Committees established
2.1 No social cohesion measurement tool developed 2.2 Twenty LRCs are already established under FFIS project in Ninewa, Salah al Din, Anbar, Kirkuk
Output 3: Partners to conduct joint preparatory work towards the establishment of a Citizens Archive
3.1 No citizen archive has been done in Iraq
Baselines as of 2019 restructuring:
Output 1: Reconciliation and social cohesion awareness campaigns in target communities are designed and carried out
1.1 No Iraqi champions of reconciliation recruited and capacitated (disaggregated by gender) 1.2 0 of public awareness campaigns on social cohesion conducted
Output 2: Active effective networks of Community Peace Platforms are established
2.1 24 Local Peace Committees established and functioning 2.2 0 youth peace groups established and functioning 2.3 No nation-wide community reconciliation conferences held 2.4 0 media professionals trained (gender disaggregated
Output 3 Vulnerable women and girls provided with psychosocial support and support creation of women peace groups
3.1 No female social workers trained to provide support to victims of SGBV 3.2 No women and girls reached for psychosocial support 3.3 0 women peace groups established

Indicators established in 2017:
Output 1: Awareness campaigns to inform target communities of the peace committees and Citizen Archive are designed and carried out
1.1/1.2 50 Iraqi champions of reconciliation are recruited and capacitated 1.3 Reconciliation messages disseminated to at least 60% of Iraqi population 1.4 Gain support from key Iraqi stakeholders for process to determine the principles of the National Reconciliation 1.5 New baseline assessment conducted and established benchmark for M&E to measure levels of Integrated Community-Led Reconciliation
Outcome 2: Active effective networks of Local Reconciliation Committees established
2.1 20 LRCs established and capacitated 2.2 3-4 inter-linked networks of new and existing reconciliation committees, bodies, and initiatives operating at district, provincial, and national levels 2.3 Development of a social cohesion measurement tool 2.4 One community reconciliation conference is held to bring communities from across the country to develop civic perspectives on reconciliation
Output 3: Partners to conduct joint preparatory work towards the establishment of a Citizens Archive
3.1 Working together to reach an agreement on establishing a Citizens Archive

-The UNDP/IFCNR/SCCP partnership has successfully established 25 LPCs, in Anbar (12), Salah Al-Din (4), Nineveh (7) and Diyala (2). In Anbar, the UNDP, SANAD (Local NGO) and the Governor’s Office supported the establishment of LPCs through a public consultative process, involving more than 560 men and women; and a similar process was followed in Salah Al-Din. - In Salah Al-Din 147 LPC members (Dujail, Tikrit, Balad, Samara and Dour), 48 representatives of the 12 LPCs in Anbar (Central LPC, Ramadi, Fallujah, Khalidya, Heeth, Qa’em, Amiryyat Al-Somoud, Rutba, Haditha, Anah, Rawa and Qarma) 240 potential LPCs members in Nineveh Plains, Sinjar, Tal Afar, Mosul-East, Mosul-West and Mosul-South and Nineveh West, 10 members of IFCNR/SCCP and 5 UNDP local facilitators (a total of 450 actors) upgraded their skills during an intensive training programme, covering topics such as analysing types of conflict, conflict components, conflict drivers, active listening, facilitation skills and problem-solving techniques, general concepts of mediation, mediator preparation and roles and active mediator conceptions. They also gained insights as how to design a dialogue process and establish local peace structures and how to communicate with the public. These trainings further included discussions, brainstorming, interactive presentations, working groups, experience sharing and case studies. - In addition, the IRP assisted the Sinjar and Nineveh Plains LPCs (a total of 80 LPC members) to develop their action plans, define priorities, short- and medium-term activities and goals, M&E plan, timetable and resources necessary for the implementation of the activities, as well as allocating the roles and responsibilities to each of the LPC members. At the same time, the LPC members also learned how to follow up on recommendations and communicate with the local, regional and federal authorities and the communities. - in Anbar, the Governor’s advisor for IDP affairs and the Falluja, Qa’em, Ramadi, Central Anbar, Amiriyat Al-Somoud and Khalidya LPCs, supported by the UNDP local facilitator in Anbar, facilitated the safe and sustainable return of 321 families, totalling more than 2,000 women, men, girls and boys, to their homes. The advisor’s team registered all the families, organised their transportation and coordinated with the security institutions to grant them safety. - the Khalidya IDP Camp closed in September 2018. The camp was open in 2015, accommodating more than 15000 IDPs from different Anbar districts. Based on the actions of various local, regional and federal authorities and the actions of the Anbar LPCs, all IDPs were returned to their homes and the camp was closed. - In coordination with SANAD and the UNDP, the LPCs organised consultations with communities, defining their most vital issues pertaining to reconciliation: 1) in Tikrit, discussions focused on the release of detainees; 2) in Balad, on the safe return of around 1,500 citizens; and 3) in Dujail, on the formation of a high-level operations room to coordinate activities of all security forces. - In addition to the work of LPCs in September 2017, the UNDP and the Council of Ministers Secretariat (COMSEC) conducted intensive roundtable sessions with each ethno-religious community and in all key cities in the Nineveh Plains, bringing together community and religious leaders, political figures, civil society and representatives of the private sector. The process culminated in a national minorities’ conference where the Prime Minister, together with UNDP and minorities’ leadership launched a Social Cohesion Road Map for the Nineveh Plains in Bartela in March 2018. This event managed to bring together more than 300 participants from different minorities and ethno-religious groups, religious leaders, political figures, civil society and representatives of the private sector. After the conference the GoI adopted 16 action points that frame the immediate needs of conflict-affected minority groups, such as basic service delivery, improved security, job creation, an enabling environment for safe and sustainable return of IDPs and included fostering the conditions for reconciliation through the establishment of LPCs in Nineveh Plains and Sinjar. - The UNDP assisted the IFCNR/SCCP to organize 19 consultative workshops on community reconciliation across Iraq in April 2018, gathering more than 1,500 representatives of academia, women and youth groups, and community leaders to discuss how to be more involved in the reconciliation process and how to support IFCNR/SCCP to achieve their mandates. Those workshops provided sets of recommendations for the attention of the IFCNR/SCCP and the UNDP for the future programming and cooperation. As follow up, the IFCNR/SCCP organised another round of consultations with 80 academics from all over Iraq to establish firm partnerships with universities which will result in the development of the new curricula and promoting ideas of community peace in classrooms. - The UNDP organised six roundtable discussions in Baghdad, Mosul, Nineveh Plains, Sulaymaniyah, Diyala and Duhok with youth and social media influencers between April and September 2018, in collaboration with IFCNR/SCCP, gathering over 120 participants from across Iraq. An e-group of supporters amongst them has been established with more than 30 social media influencers who volunteered to support an ongoing UNDP social media campaign to promote community reconciliation amongst Iraqi youth. - To date, the digital platform has reached over 11,000 likes and followers from all over Iraq, with an increased number of participants from Mosul and Nineveh, thanks to the support of an online volunteer group that was established after the roundtables. -In addition, information about the project’s activities posted on the UNDP and partners’ websites and social media channels (UNDP Facebook page, digital campaign Facebook page, the Sawtuha website, the NEC NGO Facebook page etc.) have reached, cumulatively, more than 15,000 followers. For example, we can mention the following platforms: UNDP Facebook and twitter post on the Nineveh Plains LPC’s training reached out more than 4,300 people and was liked by 50. - In line with the United Nations General Assembly Plan of Action to Prevent Violent Extremism (A/70/674) and the Amman Youth Declaration on Youth, Peace and Security, in collaboration with the IFNRC/SCCP the project started establishing the Youth Peace Groups (YPG) in the liberated areas to advocate for social cohesion in communities and promote values of peaceful coexistence as tools for preventing violent conflicts.The consultations to establish those groups started on 21 September, on the International Day of Peace celebration, gathering 91 youths from various ethno-religious groups (Shia, Sunni, Shabak, Christians, Turkman, Yazidis etc.) from across Nineveh (including Mosul, Nineveh Plains, Sinjar, Tal Afar and Qaraqosh/Hamdaniya/Baghdeda) and youth IDPs living in camps around Erbil. Members of the Nineveh YPG will be selected from the aforementioned 91 participants of the International Day of Peace event, following the criteria for the selection of members of LPCs. - The project produced four PSAs involving four Iraqi celebrities advocating for peaceful coexistence and reconciliation. The celebrities are: Zainab Al-Eqabi, a public figure who survived a bomb explosion that resulted in losing her left leg; Fareed Lafta, a civil pilot and athlete, the first cosmonaut from Iraq and the first skydiver who climbed and reached the top of Mount Everest (recorded in Guinness World Records); Ghadad Rasul, an Iraqi novelist from Mosul and a professor at the Mosul University; and Noor Sabri, one of the most famous goalkeepers in Iraqi football history. - In April 2018 the third UNDP-supported Innovation for Development Forum (#innov4dev) took place in Baghdad, gathering over 350 representatives of Government of Iraq, private investorsand companies, banks, universities and youth. This year the #Innov4dev Forum included social cohesion as one of its key themes. Part of the process was therefore to invite submissions on proposed social cohesion projects, driven by youth in their communities. Out of 300 submissions received, 44 were selected to go through a process of online voting which will determine the winners, each of whom will receive a micro-grant from the UNDP to implement their proposals. In addition, 23 start-ups with significant potential to develop social cohesion were presented during the Forum. The ideas and projects presented during the Forum paved the way for the development of a youth contest which will focus directly on the inclusion of youth in reconciliation processes. Based on the success of the #Innov4dev, in coordination with IFCNR/SCCP, the project initiated the Youth Contest for Social Cohesion, for projects aiming to engage youth from different backgrounds, working in a collaborative way with their peers from all the Iraqi governorates, to enhance social cohesion in their communities. An online call for applications was advertised reaching more than 30,000 youth, whilst more than 200 project ideas were received. The project preselected 20 entries to be presented to the selection panel composed of the IFCNR/SCCP, the Ministry of Youth, UNDP and civil society. The selection panel selected six projects to be implemented with the UNDP support, creating as many opportunities to convey the peaceful coexistence messages. - To date, the UNDP has trained 116 social workers on how to provide better support to victims of gender-based violence (GBV) in line with MOLSA’s work, without causing harm.The goal is to provide more efficient interim support to these victims and learn lessons which may be applicable to later mechanisms, centred on victims. - Out of the 116 trained social workers, 30 were screened in consultation with MOLSA for the follow up advance training on how to interview and collect data from the victims of GBV, to enable women to share their stories, detail their needs and make their demands for redress in a secure environment. To date, the 30 social workers collected more than 100 stories from the victims of GBV from Nineveh, Salah Al-Din, Diyala, Anbar, Baghdad, Karbala, Babil, Misan, Kirkuk and Basrah. The stories are being analysed by the UNDP national expert who will develop an analytical study how to re-design existing MOLSA protocols to strengthen victim assistance policies. - As a follow up on the Women’s Conference, the project organised consultations with more than 100 women from Diyala (December 2017), Nineveh (February 2018) and Anbar (September 2018) to establish Women’s peace groups. The purpose of the Women’s Peace Groups is to advocate for social cohesion and peaceful coexistence in their communities, as well as to assist local LPCs to resolve community conflicts which are of particular concern of women. To date the Nineveh Women’s Peace Group has been particularly active, organising two Bazars in Mosul and Basheeqa, reaching around 1,000 representatives of the Nineveh ethno-religious groups, and aiming to advocate for peace, reconciliation and social cohesion through the women-crafted local art works, songs and traditional dances. Members of the Nineveh Women’s Peace Group have a great impact on enhancing and highlighting the role of women in community reconciliation and peace building, since some of them endured difficult times during ISIL occupation. After the liberation they took an active role to overcome sectarian divide and conquer fear they were living in, directly contributing to achieving social cohesion in the Nineveh Governorate. SCORE INDEX: - Contingency plan: According to contingency plan, in March 2018, the final questionnaire was piloted in a second series of 12 focus groups in 10 governorates (thereby bringing the total number of governorates covered in the conceptual phase to 18). Additionally, 110 respondents answered the final questionnaire. The top four challenges expressed by the focus groups participants across 18 governorates, were: o Declining economy and high youth unemployment leading to crime, loss of livelihood, disintegration of families/communities and economic insecurity. o Failing health and education sectors, voiced more strongly by women participants. o Corruption, linked to sectarianism, nepotism, intergroup tension, armament and lack of trust/confidence in governance institutions o The failing public sector, and particularly failing law enforcement/security sector linked both to ineffectiveness, lack of capacity and corruption. - Other key findings included youth issues which were predominantly related to substance abuse, poor provision of education, lack of socialization opportunities and high unemployment. Forced underage marriages were noted in Babil and harmful religious rituals/practices were noted in Thi’Qar. Severe marginalization and harassment of Sabian and Romani youth and women were noted in Qadissiya. In general, women’s priorities are more focused on youth, health and education. For the most part coexistence was appreciated and accepted across the country and diversity is celebrated, except in Babil and Wassit, but also to an extent in Diyala. Yet sectarianism and provocative/exclusionary narratives in addition to prevalence of firearms and economic insecurity were highlighted as stressors. Government and leaders were blamed for exacerbating the situation and creating tensions in communities, as well as corruption and nepotism.

Output 1: Reconciliation and social cohesion awareness campaigns in target communities are designed and carried out
1.1 10 of Iraqi champions of reconciliation recruited and capacitated (disaggregated by gender) 1.2 20 public awareness campaigns on social cohesion conducted
Output 2: Active effective networks of Community Peace Platforms are established
2.1 25 Local Peace Committees established and functioning 2.2 6 youth peace groups established and functioning 2.3 0 nation-wide community reconciliation conferences held 2.4 N/A media professionals trained (gender disaggregated)
Output 3 Vulnerable women and girls provided with psychosocial support and support creation of women peace groups
3.1 150 female social workers trained to provide support to victims of SGBV 3.2 500 women and girls reached for psychosocial support 3.3 4 women peace groups established

However, 2 young media professional forums took place at the University of Anbar in Ramadi and the University of Mosul to discuss the role of media and youth in promoting social cohesion.

3.1 70 female social workers trained to provide support to victims of SGBV 3.2 330 women and girls reached for psychosocial support 3.3 5 women peace groups established and functional in Salah al Din, Kirkuk, Sinjar, Tel Afar, Ninewa Plain

Output 1: Reconciliation and social cohesion awareness campaigns in target communities are designed and carried out
1.1 30 Iraqi champions of reconciliation recruited and capacitated (17 women, 13 men) 1.2 9 public awareness campaigns on social cohesion conducted. In addition, with the creation of the Tanoua website, 240 media products have been published by young journalists.
